Today’s visits/activities/stops include; • Stop at Rakaposhi View Point Ghulmet • Baltit Fort • Karimabad Bazaar • Walk Along Barbar Water Channel

CENTRAL HUNZA & NAGAR In the morning visit Hoper Nagar and then Altit & Duiker. Today’s visits/activities/stops include; • Ganish Cluster – the oldest settlement of Hunza Valley • Hopar Nagar – from where you have an excellent view of Golden Peak, Ultar Peak, Hunza Peak & Lady Finger. • Altit Fort • Altit Cluster/Altit Village • Sunset from the Eagle’s Nest View Point in Duiker

UPPER HUNZA Karimabad-Atta Abad Lake: 18 kms/25 minutes’ drive Visit Dong rock inscriptions, Gulmit, Hussaini Bridge & Passu in the upper Hunza. Overnight stay at Atta Abad Lake. Today’s visits/activities/stops include; • Dong Rock Inscriptions • Atta Abad Lake • Gulmit Village • Hussaini Bridge • Passu Cones/Passu Cathedrals
UPPER HUNZA Rest day at Attabad Lake, no activities planned.

UPPER HUNZA - GILGIT-GUPIS Attabad Lake-Gilgit: 135 km/2.30 hrs drive Gilgit-Gupis: 109 kms/4 hours’ drive Drive to Gilgit and then to Gupis visiting Kargah Buddha on the way. Today’s visits/activities/stops include • Kargah Buddha • Drive to along Ghizer river • Beautiful villages along the road

GUPIS - MASTUJ Gupis– Mastuj: 150 kms/7 hours’ drive Drive to Mastuj via Phander & Shandur Pass. Today’s activities / visits include; • Phander Lake • Shandur Pass – The highest polo ground in the world

MASTUJ – CHITRAL Mastuj- Chitral: 120 kms/4 hours’ drive Drive from Mastuj to Chitral. Upon arrival transfer to hotel. Half day sightseeing & overnight stay in Chitral. Today’s visits/activities/stops include; • Tirich Mir View Point • Shahi Mosque • Chitral Bazaar
Rest day in Chitral

CHITRAL - KAILASH Chitral – Bumburet Kailash: 22 kms/1 hour’s drive In the morning visit Chitral Gol National Park. After lunch drive to Bumburet via Rambur. Today’s visits/activities/stops include • Chitral Gol National Park • Rambur Valley Kailash

KAILASH Full day for exploring the unique of Kailash Valley and its people. Short walks in the valley. Today’s visits/activities/stops include; • Chitral Museum • Traditional Homes • Their Sacred Places
KAILASH –MINGORA SWAT Bumburet Kailash – Mingora Swat: 246 kms/7 hours’ drive Drive from Kailash to Swat. Upon arrival visit Swat Museum.
SWAT Rest day to relax and do things at your own pace.

MINGORA SWAT –TAKHT-E-BHAI- PESHAWAR Swat- Takht-e-Bhai-Peshawar: 184 kms/4 hours’ drive Drive to Peshawar visiting Takht-e-Bhai and other Ghandhara sites on the way. Today’s visits/activities include • Butkara • Shingardar Stupa • Amluk Dara Stupa • Najigram Stupa • Buddhist Monastery in Takht Bhai

PESHAWAR – ISLAMABAD Peshawar- Islamabad: 186 kms/2.5 hours’ drive Today’s visits/activities include • Peshawar Museum • Mahabat Khan Mosque • Qissa Khawani Bazar • Bala Hissar Fort (exterior) • Saithi House
Departure from Islamabad

generalInfo: This encompassing adventure of Pakistan’s spectacular northern regions takes travellers to a land where the scenery is simply among the best on the planet. We begin by exploring the modern capital of Islamabad, before making our way towards Baltistan, travelling the fabled Karakoram Highway and the spectacular seasonal Babusar Pass. We explore the Hunza, an area of jaw-dropping magnificence blessed with idyllic villages and people of genuine warmth, a region that some purport to have inspired the legend of Shangri La. Along the way we will delve into the rich history – a chain of dramatic forts and watchtowers as well as other historical wonders such as ancient petroglyphs. We also join local people in vibrant bazaars, feasting on local dishes, marvelling at mighty glaciers and shimmering turquoise lakes carving through dramatic valleys, and of course pausing endlessly to drink in the inspiring panoramas of the snowclad summits of the Himalaya and Karakorum ranges.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Islamabad (Altitude: 540m) - Upon arrival, a member of our local team will be waiting to greet you at the airport and transfer to your hotel. Tomorrow morning at breakfast there will be a tour briefing with your local guide to outline the adventure ahead. Overnight Hotel de Papae, or similar. No meals are included today.

Islamabad (Altitude: 540m) - After a breakfast tour-briefing with the guide, your journey starts with an exploration of the capital Islamabad and nearby Rawalpindi. Sites in the former will include, the Shah Faisal Mosque, once the largest example in the world and elegantly modelled on a vast Bedouin tent, the Government buildings on Constitution Avenue, Shakar Parian Park with its aromatic rose and jasmine garden, the Pakistan Monument, a fascinating beautiful modern petal-design structure and the Lok Virsa heritage museum. From there you will cross into Punjab to experience the sensory explosion of the Raja Bazaar area in neighbouring Rawalpindi where a chaos of colours urges you to buy anything from a salwar kameez to a copper saucepan, and from there to Daman-e-Koh, a peaceful hillside vantage point which gazes out over the emerald expanses toward the twin cities. Overnight Hotel de Papae or similar (BL)

Islamabad – Hasan Abdal – Naran (Approximate driving time today is 6 hours) - (Altitude: Islamabad 540m – highest around 2409m - Naran 2409m) - Today you will rise early to hit a small part of the fabled KKH at around 8am and drive steadily northwards towards your goal of Naran. Stopping at Hasan Abdal will provide you with some insight into the intricate skill of truck-art painting: many HGVs that ply this route are colourfully adorned and you can’t help but be entertained by the array of dazzling examples that trundle by as you head north. Later, a stop close to Manshera will reveal the intricately etched Asoka Rock Edicts, dating back to the 3rd century BC and written in the ancient Indic script of Gandhara culture. The site has been submitted for inclusion as a World Heritage Site and, whilst faded and battered, they offer a sense of the richness of the Maurya Empire. Thereafter you continue to Naran. Overnight PTDC Motel or similar (BL)

Naran – Gilgit (Approximate driving time today is 5 hours) - (Altitude: Naran 2409m – Babusar Pass highest point is 4173m – Gilgit 1500m) - You will drive through the lush green Kaghan Valley, following the Kunhar river all the way up to the beautiful Lulusar Lake where we will make a small stop. We then continue up to the top of the impressive Babusar Pass (4173m) which provides our entry towards the Gilgit-Baltistan region. From here we head to the main city of Gilgit, your route crosses the impressive Raikot Bridge and heads sinuously through the crisp air until you break awhile at a viewpoint where, if the skies are clear, it should afford views of the majestic peak of Nanga Parbat Mountain at 8216m. A little further north and the convergence of the Indus and Gilgit Rivers is attained, hard by Jaglot. A break is a must since it is here that three of the world’s greatest mountain ranges converge: the Karakoram, Hindukush and the mighty Himalaya, a perfect storm of titanic proportions. Along the way we will make small stops to examine the ubiquitous Buddhist petroglyphs left by various invaders, traders and pilgrims who passed along the trade route, as well as by local devotees. The earliest carvings date back to between 5000 and 1000 BC, depicting single animals, triangular men and hunting scenes in which the prey sometimes appear to ominously dwarf the hunters. Incredibly, the earliest of these carvings were engraved into the rocks with primitive stone tools and are covered with a thick patina that indicates their antiquity. Emerging into the unexpected irrigated emerald expanses that surround Gilgit, there will be time to explore several sites including the bustling Gilgit Bazaar area as well as the dramatic Kargah Buddha outside town; standing some 50 feet high and dating from the 7th century, it stands sentinel over the valley under a natural canopy of frowning rock. Overnight Gilgit Grand Continental Hotel or similar (BL)

Gilgit – Ghizer Valley (Altitude: Gilgit 1500m) - Spend the day exploring the beautiful Ghizer Valley and stop at small villages along the way. Overnight Gilgit Grand Continental Hotel or similar (BL)

Gilgit – Skardu (Approximate driving time today is 3-4 hours) - (Altitude: Gilgit 1500m – Skardu 2230m) - Our exploration of these high valleys sweeps east and away from the KKH for a few days immersing yourself in the less-populated and stunning scenery of the upper reaches of the Indus – the Baltistan region. As the road gradually rises, you will enjoy the constant changing scenery at every new turn and will visit various small villages along the way to get a feel for local life. In the afternoon we can explore the Skardu bazaar area. Overnight Summit Hotel, or similar, in Skardu (BL)

Skardu - Deosai plateau day trip (4114m) - Approximate driving time today is 6 hours) - (Altitude: Skardu 2230m– Deosai plateau highest point 4114m – Skardu 2230m) - We make a day trip to the beautiful Deosai National Park, one of the highest plateaus in the world. The park protects an area of 3,000 square kilometres. It is well known for its rich flora and fauna of the Karakoram-West Tibetan Plateau alpine steppe Eco region. In the Spring season it is covered by sweeps of wildflowers and a wide variety of butterflies. When driving up to the plateau we will make a short stop at the Satpara Lake, today we have a good chance of seeing Himalyan marmots and we will also visit the Sheosar Lake which gives great reflections in its clear water of the incredible surroundings. Overnight Summit Hotel, or similar, in Skardu (BL) (Deosai plateau is only possible in the summer months - outside of this period there will be too much snow, we will then arrange an alternative sightseeing program)

Shigar Valley (Approximate driving time today is 3 hours) - (Altitude: Skardu 2230m – Shigar Valley 2430m – Skardu 2230m) - Heading out on a side-excursion of sightseeing in this simply breathtaking region, we explore the Shigar valley dotted with tiny and attractive villages; all held in the far-reaching gaze of the 16th Century Skardu Fort which affords panoramic views of the wider valley and Karakoram Range and beyond. You may also visit the Katpana Desert, one of the world’s highest cold deserts whose silky grey dunes seem incongruous amidst the gritty surroundings. Nearby, Shigar Fort, dating from the 17th Century and recently restored, is a delightfully elegant boulder and wooden construction atop a rock, alongside a rushing stream; you will enjoy lunch here in the gardens if weather conditions allow. Overnight Summit Hotel, or similar, in Skardu (BL)

Skardu – Khaplu (Approximate driving time is 3 hours) - (Altitude: Skardu 2230m – highest around 2700m – Khaplu 2601m) - Further still into the dizzying delights of the Saltoro Range, as you follow the enigmatically braided Shyok River, choked with meltwater boulders and shingle. A magnificent 3-hour drive, marvelling at the raw jagged outlines of the peaks that shear brutally from the rooftop of the world, brings you to the sanctuary of Khaplu a village sheltered in the crook of the Karakoram Mountains. From this historic fortified settlement, you will enjoy a gentle walk to a viewpoint with incredible panoramic views and whose window on the rank after rank of high altitude ranges simply beggars belief. Enjoy lunch at wonderfully restored Khaplu Palace and thereafter take a tour of the palace complex and the 700-year-old Chaqchan Mosque, a cream washed and wooden-framed gem of architecture. You may be fortunate to catch sight of the majestic mountain icon that is Masherbrum (7,821 m) from here. Overnight Karakorum Lodge or similar (BL)

Khaplu – Gilgit (Approximate driving time today is 6 hours) - (Altitude: Khaplu 2601m – Gilgit 1500m) - Leaving the heady delights of Baltistan behind, you will retrace your steps towards Skardu, this time with the sun on your left, illuminating the beige-coloured frowning crags and longs scree slides against the deep cobalt of the skies. Watch out for flocks of snow pigeons in the valley and wandering ibex on the higher slopes. At lunchtime, a side road soldiers up to one of the regions most celebrated viewpoint – the idyllic glassy vantage point of Kachura Lake. Nicknamed ‘Shangri-La Lake’ owing to a resort named after a fabled Buddhist retreat, the name literally ‘Heaven on Earth’ and it is hard to argue, since the vista here at the opening up of the Indus valley is a photographer’s nirvana. From here you descend into down to the Indus gorge to Gilgit for your accommodation. Overnight Gilgit Continental hotel, or similar (BL)

Gilgit – Rakaposhi (Approximate driving time today is 1.5 – 2 hours) - (Altitude: Gilgit 1500m – Rakaposhi viewpoint 1995m) - After breakfast we turn north and up the Hunza River to continue your Karakoram Highway ascent, flanked by the ever increasing elevations of the resplendent snow-clad Himalayan and Karakoram ranges. Near Chalt, at a seemingly insignificant buttress of rock, you will stop to find out why this is the epicentre of the colossal topographical feature of the highest massif in the world: here, 55 million years ago, the Indian Continental plate collided with the Eurasian plate and forced up the Himalayas which still rise about 1cm annually. Oddly, this is precisely the spot in which local bridal processions also used to pause to make sacrifices before the collision of two different cultures! As your route swings eastwards, the road is suddenly dominated by the great goliath of Rakaposhi Peak shimmering white, whose arêtes and tongues of glaciers almost seem to descend to the green valley bottom. Here you will come upon Thole Nagar, where there will be an opportunity to sample the local delicacy of chapshoro (a regional take on pizza). Arriving at Rakaposhi village, there will be time to relax and drink in the awesome beauty of Rakaposhi’s 7,788m. Overnight local guesthouse or similar (BL)

Rakaposhi – Karimabad and the Hunza Valley (Approximate driving time is 1 hour) - (Altitude: Rakaposhi viewpoint 1995m – highest at Duikar sunset around 2850m - Karimabad 2500m) - Today’s short but spectacular drive to Karimabad clings to the steep sides of the mountain above the crumbling chasm of the Hunza River. Karimabad is the main town of the Hunza Valley region and a real cultural and historic hub. You will explore the area, meeting with local people and trying to gauge an understanding of the secrets of their longevity. After a lunch of traditional Hunza dishes, you visit some of the prominent historical sites such as Baltit Fort, former seat of the Mirs of Hunza and perched on wedding-cake-like tiers of cobbles, the ancient Silk Road village of Ganish – ‘village of gold’ – and its watch tower, and Altit Fort which gazes imperiously from its precipitous seat across the expanses of the valley. Later enjoy the kaleidoscopic shifts in colours on the soaring summits at sunset from the stunning viewpoint in Duikar. Overnight Hunza Embassy Lodge (BL)

Nagar Valley and Hopar glacier (Approximate driving time is 3 – 4 hours) - (Altitude: Karimabad 2500m – Nagar Valley & Hopar glacier day trip 2820m) - Today your base camp remains in Hunza: you take a day trip to the remote Nagar Valley, situated at an elevation of around 2500 metres above sea level to visit some of the idyllic and peaceful villages which cluster around the broad-bottomed glacial flats or cling to the steep slopes along zig-zagging tracks and meet with local people. From here, we forge higher into the Hopar Valley which transitions from meltwater streams to the snout of one of the fastest moving glaciers in the world – the Hopar Glacier – a sobering sight which encapsulates the unimaginable power of nature as it grinds down the grooves in the mountain, creating the incredible landscape you see before you. Overnight Hunza Embassy Lodge or similar (BL) Note – Hopar Glacier Walk: For those that wish to walk from the vehicle to the glacier the walk takes around 1 hour each way and involves both ascent and descent on variable terrain. The walk should be undertaken by those with good footwear and who are of a reasonable trekking fitness. For those that do not wish to walk there are places to sit where refreshments are available whilst enjoying the photographic opportunities afforded by the views of the glacier and beyond.

Karimabad – Gulmit – Passu – Gulmit (Approximate driving time is 3 hours) - (Altitude: Karimabad 2500m – Gulmit – Passu highest around 2665m – Gulmit 2465m) - Today you continue to eastwards towards Gulmit and the Upper Hunza via the newly constructed road. The road initially clings to the north-facing slopes of the valley, giving you superb vistas of the sunlit peaks in the Batura Muztagh range which rises to 7,795m. As the route starts to back northwards, you will stop and stretch your legs beside the superb scenery of Attabad Lake, which, bizarrely, has only existed a few years, created by a massive landslide blocking the flow of the Hunza River for months in 2010. The crisis that ensued as the valley’s villages were displaced to the hillsides resulted in a $275 million project to reinstate the KKH with a new tunnel, completed in 2015. On arrival at Gulmit, ‘Valley of the Flowers’, which clings to the northern slopes above the Hunza, you explore the town and surrounding area including the Passu glacier and the precarious Hussaini hanging bridge. In Gulmit village, visit the museum with its unique collection showcasing the rich fabric of Hunza history, its polo ground, and a local traditional music school (subject to permission). Either later today or early tomorrow there will also be an option for those that wish to undertake a hike to Kamaris village from which one can enjoy superb views on a clear day. The walk is around 1 hour each way and is of an easy grade, involving some up and downhill sections. A particular joy is the incredible outline of Topopdan Peak, with its array of secondary pinnacles which rise like spectacular royal icing from its snowy buttresses. Overnight Silk Route Lodge or similar (BL)

Gulmit – Minapin (Approximate driving time is 2.5 hours) - (Altitude: Gulmit 2465m – Minapin 2200m) - Having reached the northernmost point of your traversing the KKH, only 114km from the Khunjerab Pass and the gateway to China, you begin to head back south to Minapin, at the heart of the Nagar Valley, ascending the small hill-roads to reach this spot, sequestered far away from the well-trodden highway. This is climbers’ country too: every season, this is the starting point for approaches to Rakaposhi and Diran base camps, and weather permitting you too will enjoy superb views of the mountains from here. On arrival, you spend the time exploring the village and learn how to cook a traditional Nagar meal which is prepared in a stone pot. Thereafter, there will be time to relax and imbibe the sublime scenery and overridingly peaceful ambience. Overnight at local guest house in Minapin (BL)

Minapin – Gilgit (Approximate driving time is 1.5 hours) - (Altitude: Minapin 2200m – Gilgit 1500m) - From Minapin you drive back to Gilgit, you make a stop enroute at a small village to sit front row at a local polo match, experiencing the raw thrills of this skilful and fast-paced horseback sport, a firm favourite activity in Pakistani culture. In the afternoon you continue to Gilgit for our overnight stay. Overnight Gilgit Continental Hotel or similar (BL)

Gilgit – Naran (Approximate driving time is 3 hours) - (Altitude: Gilgit 1500m– Babusar Pass highest point is 4173m - Naran 2409m or if via Besham 613m) - From Gilgit, we head back the way we came over the Babusar Pass to Naran. Here the turquoise waters of the river meet a narrowing, alpine-styled valley, where steep spurs are clad in coniferous trees above the settlement in the flat valley below. If time allows it, you will visit the legendary lake of Saif ul Muluk, lying at 3,200m, high above the town. The glassy waters are simply idyllic, set against the backdrop of Malika Parbat (5271m), the highest peak of the valley, which towers above, offering and the perfect opportunity for some truly memorable photographic opportunities. Overnight stay Hotel One or simiar (BL)

Naran – Taxila (UNESCO) - Islamabad (Approximate driving time today is 6 hours) - (Altitude: Naran 2409m – Taxila – Islamabad 540m or if via Besham 613m – highest point around 1500m – Islamabad 540m) - After an early breakfast you start the last stage of your journey, descending first down the increasingly fertile green Kunhar River’s banks. The temperature starts to rise as your route drops in altitude. Here the Kaghan valley, a verdant spread of small farming villages, attracts people from the cities to its lower reaches in the warmer months. This afternoon your will visit the important archaeological site of Taxila (a UNESCO World Heritage Site) where you will also have lunch. You then continue to the capital of Islamabad to complete this epic journey through Northern Pakistan. As a special goodbye, this evening you will enjoy a farewell dinner at Monal restaurant atop the Margalla Hills and eat great local food while gazing down towards Islamabad and Rawalpindi. Overnight Hotel de Papae or similar (BLD)
Depart Islamabad (Altitude: 540m) - Transfer to the airport for your onward flight. (B)

placesVisited: Islamabad, Chitral, Kalash Valleys, Mastuj, Gilgit, Hunza Valley, Karakorum Highway, Khaplu, Deosai Plateau, Besham, Taxila
generalInfo:
This Northern Pakistan holiday takes you on a small group adventure to one of Asia’s most fascinating regions, home to jaw dropping landscapes and diverse ethnic groups whose traditions have remained unchanged for centuries.

The tour kicks off with a tour of the lively, modern capital Islamabad before heading northwest to Chitral, a wild, remote and beautiful region next to the Afghanistan border, home to the unique Kalash people, who are sometimes described as pagans thanks to their cultural beliefs. On this trip you’ll be able to see their ancient ways in action at the vibrant annual Uchal Festival.

Next, you’ll head overland through the Hindu Kush to Gilgit, a truly memorable journey during which you’ll cross the famous Shandur pass with a backdrop of stunning snowcapped mountain peaks. Then you’ll make your way to the region of Hunza, home to friendly people and landscapes so beautiful they’re said to have inspired the legend of Shangri La.

Here you’ll visit ancient forts, view massive glaciers and get to know a land that will shatter any preconceptions you have about Pakistan. Highlights include a ferry journey across Lake Attabad to visit Hunza’s former summer capital of Hunza; an exploration of Baltistan, whose landscapes are reminiscent of Tibet; and a journey across the rugged Deosai Plateau, where wolves, bears and other wildlife roam.

Taking the Karakoram Highway back south, you’ll visit the legendary Buddhist site of Taxila before finishing in Islamabad for your flight home.

dayInfo.description: Islamabad - Arrive in Islamabad and transfer to your hotel. This afternoon we head out to explore the city, visiting the Faisal Mosque and the Daman e Koh for a view over the capital. Overnight Envoy Continental Hotel or similar.

Chitral - Fly to Chitral, over the fertile green plains of valley of Swat and the Lowari pass (3,200m). The landscape of the Hindu Kush range appears arid and dry, as this area is outside the reach of monsoon and receives very little rain. In the afternoon, we have time to visit the colourful bazaar and mingle with people from different parts of Afghanistan and North Pakistan. Enjoy stunning views of Tirich Mir (7,708m) the highest mountain of the Hindu Kush, and visit the central Mosque of the town. Overnight PTDC Chitral Motel or similar. (BLD)

Chitral – Kalash Valleys - Spend the morning exploring Chitral; we visit the historic Shahi Mosque as well the fort, where a small contingent of the British army was besieged for almost a month during the period of colonial expansion. From the fort is a superb view of Tirich Mir and the Chitral River. This afternoon we drive south west, to the valleys of the Kalash people, one of Pakistan’s most fascinating ethnic groups. Overnight PTDC Bamburet Motel or similar. (BLD)

Kalash Valleys - Spend two days exploring the lands of the Kalash. The Kalash are a pagan infidel tribe believing in the old gods, known to the outside world for their vibrant traditions and very unlike the other ethnic groups of Pakistan. Legend says that they are the descendants of four Greek soldiers of Alexander’s army. The women wear black robes and a skull-cap decorated with sea shells and coins. We visit the valleys of Birir, Rambur and Bamburet to see unique cattle houses, ancient deities and picturesque villages. Our tour has been timed to coincide with the Uchal festival to see some of the Kalash’s incredible cultural traditions. Overnight PTDC Bamburet Motel or similar. (BLD)

Mastuj - Drive to Mastuj, a beautiful village to the North-East of Chitral. The jeep track carves its way through the stark and rugged mountains. This traditional route has been used for centuries by traders between Chitral and Gilgit. On the way we have magnificent views of Tirich Mir and Buni Zom. Overnight PTDC Mastuj Motel or similar. (BLD)

Gilgit - Drive to Gilgit. The zigzagging perilous jeep road connects to a wide plateau with a lake and a polo field, at the famous Shandur Pass where annual polo matches are played between the Chitralis and the Gilgitis. We continue to Gilgit, bidding farewell to the Hindu Kush and driving through a wild and untamed landscape. Overnight Hotel Riviera or similar. (BLD)

Hunza - Our destination today is Karimabad, in the Hunza Valley. On the way we have excellent views of Rakaposhi and Ultar peak, stopping for tea at a viewpoint to see Rakaposhi in its all glory from summit to its glaciers. Shortly afterwards we reach Karimabad, surrounded by peaks towering above 7000 metres. Overnight Hunza View Hotel or similar. (BLD)

Hunza - Spend the day exploring the Hunza Valley. Head to Duiker to see sunrise over magnificent snow-covered peaks including Ultar (7388m), Rakaposhi (7788m) and Diran (7266m). After breakfast at Duiker, visit Altit and head to the Hoper valley on the eastern side of the Hunza River, a predominantly Shia Muslim area. Here we visit one of the world's fastest moving glaciers leading down from the Karakorum Mountains. Return to Karimabad where we visit the impressive Baltit fort. Overnight Hunza View Hotel or similar. (BLD)

Gulmit - A full day excursion to Gulmit, second biggest town in Hunza region, involving crossing Attabad lake by ferry. Gulmit, the capital of Gojal (upper Hunza) is situated on a fertile plateau and once served as the summer capital for the Mirs of Hunza. Visit some of Gulmit’s sites for more of an insight into the traditional culture of the region, including the Gulmit museum - with its traditional ethnic artefacts from the region, the former Mir’s residence, and traditional houses. Return to Karimabad in the afternoon. Overnight Hunza View Hotel or similar. (BLD)

Skardu - Today, we follow the Gilgit river downstream and travel on the Karakorum Highway eventually crossing the Gilgit river, at the confluence point of the Karakorum, Himalaya and Hindu Kush. Crossing the Gilgit river we head upstream along the Indus River, zigzagging through the narrow gorges of the Karakorum which eventually open up to capital of Baltistan, Skardu. Overnight K2 Motel or similar. (BLD)

Khaplu - Drive to the picturesque village of Khaplu and visit its fort and mosques. Depending on the weather we may be able to see the mighty Masherbrum (7,821 m) from here. Return to Skardu for the night. Overnight K2 Motel or similar. (BLD)

Deosai Plateau - Rama - A long but rewarding day, crossing the Deosai Plateau, a treeless wilderness at 4,000m. After lunch at Bara Pani, we cross a suspension bridge with our jeeps – an exhilarating experience! Deosai Plateau is now a National Park and home to more than forty Himalayan brown bear, one of Pakistan’s most endangered species, as well as wolf, ibex and other species. Overnight PTDC Rama Motel or similar. (BLD)

Besham - Start our journey back south, driving along the Indus Valley on the Karakoram Highway. Our destination of the day is the small town of Besham. Overnight Besham Continental Hotel or similar. (BLD)

Islamabad - Return to Islamabad, driving through Manshera, Abbotabad and Hasanabdal. We stop to explore the archaeological site of Taxila, an early centre of Buddhism, before arriving in Islamabad, our final destination in Pakistan. Overnight Envoy Continental Hotel or similar. (BLD)
Islamabad - Transfer to the airport for departure. (B)

tourName: Northern Pakistan tour, Kingdom of Hunza
placesVisited: Islamabad and Rawalpindi, Karakoram Highway to Chilas, Fairy Meadows, Trek to Nanga Parbat Base Camp, Deosai National Park, Skadu, Satpara Lake, Shigar Valley, Khaplu, Hunza Valley, Karimabad, Nagar Valley and Upper Hunza, Khunjerab Pass
generalInfo:
Explore the former Kingdom of Hunza, spectacular Karakoram mountains and high passes, and the Deosai plains, home to the elusive snow leopard, as well as bustling bazaars and peaceful villages on this northern Pakistan tour.

Over 15 days from Islamabad you’ll follow in the footsteps of ancient traders, pilgrims and adventurers along the Silk Road, and take in the epic scenery from the Karakoram Highway. All in the company of a small group led by a local tour leader who will share with you stories and facts about the region, and make the introductions in the remote communities you pass through along the way.

The landscapes are the star of the show. You’ll traverse some of the highest mountain passes on earth, and spend a night at Fairy Meadows with the imposing Nanga Parbat, ninth-highest mountain in the world, for a backdrop. Majestic peaks continue to rear up as you cross the plains of Deosai National Park to Skardu, and the Hunza and Nagar Valleys.

But there are many pleasures to be had on a human-scale too, from rubbing shoulders with local people amid the atmospheric bazaar of Skardu, to the warm welcomes provided by your hosts in a series of locally run guesthouses. Join this tour and discover a tranquil, hospitable Pakistan far from the sensationalist headlines, along with some of the most breathtaking mountain scenery on the planet.

dayInfo.description: Arrival in Pakistan - On arrival in Islamabad, our representative will meet you outside the customs and immigration area at the airport. They will be able to answer questions, brief you on the immediate arrangements, and escort you to the hotel in Islamabad. Depending on the time of your arrival there should be time for some sightseeing in the twin cities of Islamabad and Rawalpindi. Rawalpindi and Islamabad are two cities located in the upper Punjab region of Pakistan. Rawalpindi is an old British-era settlement, while Islamabad is the capital city and administrative centre. Both cities are situated at about 1,500 feet in elevation in the hot and steamy plains. In Rawalpindi, you can wander among the many and varied bazaars or visit the imposing Shah Faisal Mosque. This mosque is one of the largest in the world, with room for 15,000 worshippers inside and 85,000 in the courtyard. We will attend a trek briefing at the Alpine Club of Pakistan. This briefing will provide us with information about the upcoming trek, including the route, difficulty level, and safety precautions. Overnight in Hotel Hill View or similar

Chilas - Today we set off to Chilas along the famous Karakoram Highway. It is certainly one of the world's most spectacular roads, tracing one of the many pathways of the ancient Silk Road.It is often called the 'Eighth Wonder of the World' due to its high elevation and the difficult conditions in which it was constructed. The Karakoram Highway is also known as the Friendship Highway in China, and was built by the governments of Pakistan and China, starting in 1959 and was completed in 1979 (opening to the public in 1986). It is thought that 810 Pakistanis and over 200 Chinese workers lost their lives, mostly in landslides and falls while building the highway. Overnight at the Shangrila Midway House or similar (B)

Fairy Meadows - This morning after breakfast we will visit the local rock carvings before starting the two hour drive to Raikot Bridge. From here, we transfer into 4WD jeeps for another hour’s drive through a narrow gorge to Tato village. We will enjoy a 2 hour trek on the pony trails through the thick covered pine forest leads to reach fairy meadows. Overnight at Raikot Sarai Camp Resort Fairy Meadows or similar (B)

Fairy Meadows - We will take an excursion towards the Nanga Parbat base camp. This ia an easy and gentle walk through the green meadows covered with thick pine and birch forests. We cross Ganalo glacier and then continue to walk through the lush green grassy meadows. Visit Alfred Drexel monument and explore the area. After lunch we will trek back to Fairy meadows. (total of 7 hours walking /trek). Overnight at Raikot Sarai Camp Resort Fairy Meadows or similar (B)

Tarashing - We leave behind the Fairy Meadows and drive to Tarashing. Tarishing is a village with around 200 inhabitants and a sub-division of Astore District. It is considered the gateway to Nanga Parbat. It has almost 25 shops, 1 high school for boys, 1 middle school for girls, 1 private English-medium school, two hotels and a small medical centre. A large glacier beside the Rupal river is also a part of this village, that is situated on an altitude of about 2900 metres. Overnight at Nanga Parbat Tourist Cottage or similar (B)

Skardu - Our adventure continues as we drive to the Deosai Plains, a high plateau in the Himalayas that is also the habitat of the snow leopard. We never loose sight of Nanga Parbat as we ride through the extensive meadows that are buried in snow for nine months and only reveal their velvet green cover and hundreds of flowers in the summer. Along the journey, our jeep drivers must skilfully navigate through streams that rush with glacial water. Overnight at Concordia Motel Skardu or similar (B)

Skardu - Situated on a hilltop overlooking Skardu, we will visiti Kharpocho Fort with panoramic views of the town, the Indus River, and the surrounding mountains. This ancient fort dates back to the 16th century and provides a glimpse into the region's history and architecture. We will then stroll through the bustling Skardu Old Bazaar to experience the local culture and indulge in some shopping. The market is filled with shops selling traditional handicrafts, gemstones, local produce, and dried fruits. It's an excellent place to interact with locals, sample regional delicacies, and immerse yourself in the vibrant atmosphere. Located about 9 kilometres from Skardu, our next destination is Satpara Lake, a serene and crystal-clear lake surrounded by mountains. There are options to take a boat ride on the lake, enjoy a picnic on its banks, or simply soak in the tranquillity of the surroundings. We then take a short drive to the enchanting Shigar Valley. Known for its terraced fields, fruit orchards, and traditional wooden houses, this valley offers a glimpse into the local way of life. You can explore the historic Shigar Fort, which has been converted into a heritage hotel and museum, showcasing artifacts and exhibits related to the area's history. Overnight at Concordia Motel Skardu or similar (B)

Khaplu - This handsome village of timber-and-stone houses and precision-made dry walls climbs up a wide alluvial fan beneath an arc of sheer granite walls. Painstaking irrigation has made it a shady, fertile oasis. As you climb its twisting track, the icy peaks of the Masherbrum Range rise on the other side of the valley. It’s hard to imagine a more majestic setting near a public road anywhere in Pakistan. The main attractions are the 2600m-high village itself, the old Royal Palace and the even older Mosque above it at Changchun. Oh and of course, the heart-stopping views! Overnight at Concordia Motel Skardu or similar (B)

Hunza - The Hunza Valley is a mountainous valley, situated north/west of the Hunza River, at an elevation of around 2,500 metres. Aliabad is the main town, while Baltit and Altit are popular tourist destinations due to the spectacular scenery of the surrounding mountains. The people here are cheerful and friendly and almost all speak Burushaski. The Hunzakuts are famed for their longevity, supposedly resulting from their mostly vegetarian diet of cereals and fruits. Overnight at the Karakorum View Hotel or similar (B)

Sightseeing - Today we will explore Karimabad, also known as Baltit. It is named after Prince Karim Aga Khan, the spiritual head of Shia Ismaili Nizari community. In the morning we visit the old Baltit Fort. This Tibetan style fort was originally built by the Balti Artisans, when a princess of Baltistan married a Prince of Hunza. The father of the princess sent artisans from Baltistan to build this fort in her dowery. After the Mir (king) moved to another residence, the fort has been restored by the ‘Agha Khan Trust for Culture’ as a historical asset. You will also be able to get stunning views of the Hunza and Nagar valleys from the Fort. Overnight at the Karakorum View Hotel or similar (B)

Nagar and Upper Hunza - The Nagar and Upper Hunza are two breathtaking regions located in the Gilgit-Baltistan province of Pakistan. Nestled amidst the majestic peaks of the Karakoram and Himalayan ranges, these areas offer a mesmerizing blend of natural beauty, cultural heritage, and warm hospitality. Some key attractions in Nagar Valley include the Hopper Glacier, a stunning glacier known for its icy landscapes and crystal-clear streams and Attabad Lake, a mesmerizing turquoise-coloured lake that was formed as a result of a massive landslide in 2010. The lake offers stunning views of the surrounding mountains and is a popular spot for boating and photography. In the Upper Hunza we will see the Passu Cones, a unique geological formation. These towering, jagged peaks offer a dramatic backdrop against the clear blue skies and are a popular attraction for photographers and hikers. The Hussaini Suspension Bridge is an iconic landmark in the region. It is a pedestrian bridge that spans across the Hunza River. Maybe not for the faint-hearted however, walking across the bridge provides panoramic views of the river and surrounding mountains. Overnight at the Silk Route Lodge or similar (B)

Khunjerab Pass - The Khunjerab Pass (elevation 4,733m) is a high mountain pass in the Karakoram Mountains in a strategic position on the northern border of Pakistan's Gilgit-Baltistan region and on the southwest border of the Xinjiang region of China. Its name is derived from Wakhi, 'Khun' meaning Home and 'Jerav' means spring water/water falling. The Khunjerab Pass is the highest paved international border crossing in the world and the highest point on the Karakoram Highway. The roadway across the pass was completed in 1982, and has superseded the unpaved Mintaka and Kilik Passes as the primary passage across the Karakoram. Overnight at the Silk Route Lodge or similar (B)

Chilas - Today, we will take a U-turn and start our journey back south. Along the way we will stop over at Rakaposhi View point for a tea break and to get some more photos. We will also top at Gilgit for lunch before we reach Chilas once again and our destination for the night. Overnight at the Shangrila Midway House or similar (B)

Islamabad - A busy day on the road as we return to Islamabad. We take plenty of comfort breaks and enjoy watching life go by. On arrival in Islamabad, we return to our original hotel. Overnight in Hotel Hill View or similar (B)
Depart Pakistan - At a suitable time, you will be transferred to the airport for your international departure. Our representative will say Khuda Hafiz “May God be your protector” here.

generalInfo:
Oh this exclusive 14-day tour we take you on experiential adventure so you can enjoy local markets, mosques, high tea by the Lake in Chitral, forts, castles and caves.

On this trip not only do you see and enjoy Islamabad and Lahore, but we also take you on a taste journey to enjoy local street food. Visit Chitral, home to the Kalasha Valleys and the Kalash people, as well as the Hindukush Valley and historic city of Peshawar.

You will get to see the handicraft the local women in Kalash do, see the art of making Chappli Kebabs in Peshawar from scratch, enjoy local street food, visit the Wagha Border which is the dividing line between India and Pakistan and has a daily ceremony of the hoisting of the flag, it can only be compared with changing of the guards at Buckingham Palace, although the atmosphere is significantly more electric with a great light hearted rivalry of cheers between the Indian and Pakistani crowds.

This tour has the perfect mix of natural beauty, people, culture, food and local shopping all created and developed with the local community so you can immerse yourself in the culture of Pakistan and the local community can benefit directly.

The festivals in Kalash take place on the following dates in 2025;

Chilam Joshi Festival - 13th - 16th May;
Uchal Festival 20th - 22nd August;
Choimus Festical - 15th - 22nd December

If you would like to join any of these festivals we can plan the itinerary around these dates.

dayInfo.description: Based on arrival on the previous night. Breakfast at Margalla Hills, followed by a city tour which includes visiting Faisal Mosque & Pakistan Monument.On arrival at the Islamabad you will be meet by the guide or driver and taken to the hotel for check in (Hotel Check In time is 14:00 hours). After a brief stop to freshen up at the hotel, you will begin the tour of Islamabad city. Islamabad was designed by the famous Greek architect Doxiades in the early 1960’s at the edge of the Potohar plateau. The city is divided into eight zones, including an administrative sector, diplomatic enclave, residential areas, educational sectors, industrial sectors, commercial areas, and rural and green areas. The city is known for the presence of several parks and forests, including the Margalla hills and Shakarparian park, we begin our tour at Shakerparian (or Sweet Hills) Park from where we will get a bird’s eye view of Islamabad. Nearby is the Pakistan Monument which is inspired by Moghul architecture, and has four petal-like structures symbolizing the four main cultures of the country, a small museum narrating the history and creation of Pakistan, both of which are connected by a small plaza known as the Freedom Plaza. Dinner at Monal to get a panoramic view of the city of Islamabad Overnight at Hotel.

Leave Islamabad after breakfast, making your way to Swat, also known as Switzerland of Asia because of its blue lakes, lush green pine trees and snow-capped mountains. Once in Swat, you will visit the Swat museum & Buddh Kara. Overnight stay at hotel

The day will be spent mainly on the road driving to the Kailash valley, as you drive you will see the change in topography from lush green pines to more Rocky Mountains. The Kailash valley is based in the Hindukush, one of the valleys which has been impacted by the Climate change & was visited by Prince William & Kate in 2020. Overnight at Hotel.

These two days you will spend in the valley taking part in the Uchal Festival. This is one of the top cultural festivals of Pakistan, the people of Kalash celebrate around 4 festivals during the course of the year. In the Uchal festival, the people pay homage to their God with food & crops, they prepare corn, buttermilk & cheese to celebrate the festival & rejoice uchao. Overnight at hotel.

Leave for Chitral after breakfast. After some rest at the hotel, you will be taken to visit the Shahi masjid & Chitral Bazaar. After lunch you will be taken to the Chitral Gol National Park to see the Markhor’s, the national animal of Pakistan, which come out at 5pm to go to the streams to get water. Overnight at hotel.

A day excursion to Gharam Chashma, known as the Hot Springs, will take place. However we are looking at changing this as reviews haven’t been great, so may change this to departure to Peshawar so you have an extra day in Peshawar.
Upon arrival in Peshawar, after some rest, you will be taken to explore the street food on offer in Qissa Khwani Bazaar.

The morning will take you to the visit the Sethi Mohalla, home to 7 of the most incredible pieces of architecture now protected as world heritage sites. Exploring the neighbouring clock tower & local shops which sell Afghani rugs, Peshawari Chappals a couple of items that Peshawar is famous for. After this you will depart and make your way to Taxila, on route to Islamabad. Taxila is home to the Mesolithic cave & archaeological remains of early settlement, made up of Buddhist monasteries. After this you will then go on for an overnight stay in Islamabad.

Following an early breakfast, you will leave and make your way to Rohtas Fort before going to the Wagha Border where you will enjoy the light-hearted ceremony of Pakistan’s equivalent of changing of the guards. It is a light-hearted affair with a lovely patriotic vibe on both sides India & Pakistan. Rohtas Fort is another UNESCO World heritage site, built by Sher Shah Suri. It is an exceptional example of early Muslim military architecture in Central & South Asia.

The day will comprise of a visit of many of the famous key sites made up of the Walled City of Lahore, which includes Lahore Fort & Badhshai mosque, followed by dinner at the famous Haveli restaurant, which is a lovely view overlooking the Badshahi mosque.

This will be a relaxing day, at which you can visit the local markets of Gulberg of which Anarkali is one of them. In the evening a visit to the famous Poet restaurant will be arranged which is an experience in itself. https://poetrestaurant.com/

Leave Lahore early for the drive back to Islamabad. Along the way a visit will be made to the famous Khewra Caves, 2nd largest salt mines in the world & the Katas Temple, where many Hindu’s still visit for an annual pilgrimage.
Departure to respective countries

generalInfo:
Join us on a 21 day tour as our knowledgable guides provide you with stories about all the different rulers and cultures which have influenced the incredible architecture found in the different cities & hill top stations we visit. The tour starts and ends in Islamabad, discover and learn the history behind the different forms of architecture prevailing in the country dating from different eras with influences from a variety of civilisations.

The tour will start from Islamabad & then takes you up to see the incredible mountain peaks in the North of Pakistan, where you can enjoy the incredible forts from the past. We take you to see the valley of Hunza, Skardu, famous for its cold desert & then moving across to the valleys of Chitral. As we descent to explore the urban cities of Pakistan we do so via the beautiful Swat Valley & then on to explore the oldest city in the sub-continent region, Peshawar. The tour can be done privately and be tailor made, the group tour date provided ties into the Uchaw festival which takes place from 20th -22nd August in Kailash.

This tour not only looks at the architecture bit also at the plethora of archaeological sites which date back to the era of Buddhism. You will not only be visiting mosques but also buddhist remains & Gudwara's, showcasing the influence of hinduism, sikhism, Islam and buddhism in the region.

dayInfo.description: Arrival at Islamabad Airport & transfer to Hotel.

ISLAMABAD Full day tour of Islamabad and Rawalpindi. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Shah Faisal Mosque - the largest mosque in Pakistan • Lok Virsa (Folk Heritage) Museum • Pakistan National Monument • Daman-e-Koh (Islamabad View Point) • Golra Sharif Rail Museum or Pakistan Railways Heritage Museum • External view of Parliament House, President House, Prime Minister House & Supreme Court of Pakistan • Raja Bazaar Rawalpindi

ISLAMABAD –PESHAWAR Islamabad- Peshawar: 189 kms/2.5 hours’ drive After breakfast drive to Peshawar. Upon arrival visit the places of interest and overnight in Peshawar. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Peshawar Museum-collection of Buddhist art work • Mahabat Khan Mosque built by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan • Qissa Khawani Bazar (The bazar of story tellers) • Saithi House -The Mughal Central Asian Architecture • The historic Qila Bala Hissar (Bala Hissar Fort) from outside

PESHAWAR-TAKHT BHAI-SWAT Peshawar- Takht-e-Bhai: 85 kms/1.5 hours’ drive Takht-e-Bhai – Saidu Sharif Swat: 120 kms/3 hours’ drive In the morning visit Islamia college Peshawar. After departure from Peshawar, stop at Takht-e-Bhai Archaeological sites and proceed to Saidu Sharif Swat. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Islamia College • Takht-e-Bhai archaeological sites • Enjoy local fish in Charsadda • Barikot Archaeological sites
SWAT Explore attractions/places of interest around Swat valley. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Swat Museum-showcasing collections of Gandhara Art • The Buddhist sacred Area of Budkara • Jahanabad Buddha Rock
MINGORA SWAT - KAILASH Saidu Sharif Swat -Bumburet Kailash: 246 kms/7 hours’ drive Drive from Swat to Kailash.

KAILASH VALLEY Full day for exploring the unique of Kailash Valley and its people. Short walks in the valley. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Kailash Museum • Traditional House to explore the way of life • Sacred places
KAILASH Free day to enjoy the festival

KAILASH – CHITRAL-MASTUJ Bumburet Kailash - Chitral: 22 kms/1 hour’s drive Chitral – Mastuj: 106 kms/4 hours’ drive In the morning leave for Chitral town. Visit places of interest. After lunch drive to Mastuj for overnight stay. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Chitral Bazaar • Shahi Mosque • Tirich Mir View Point • Rambur Valley Kailash

MASTUJ - GUPIS Mastuj- Gupis: 150 kms/7-8 hours’ drive Drive to Gupis via Shandur Pass and Phander valley. Overnight in Gupis. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Shandur Pass- the highest polo ground in the world • Phander Valley • Phander Lake

GUPIS - GILGIT Gupis – Gilgit: 109 kms/6 hours’ drive Drive to Gilgit from Gupis visiting Kargah Buddha on the way. KEY ATTRACTIONS • 4X4 drive along the beautiful valleys of Ghizer River • Kargah Buddha Rock

GILGIT – ATTA ABAD LAKE Gilgit - Atta Abad Lake: 115 kms/2.5 hours’ drive Drive from Gilgit to Atta Abad Lake. After lunch visit the nearby attractions. Overnight at Atta Abad Lake. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Rakaposhi viewpoint Ghulmet • Borith Lake • Hussaini Bridge

UPPER HUNZA Free day at Atta Abad Lake or day excursion to Khunjerab National Park. Overnight at Atta Abad Lake. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Khunjerab National Park • Wildlife in Khunjerab Ntional Park area • Passu Cones/Passu Cathedrals view point from KKH • Batura glacier view point from KKH • Gulmit Village museum • Atta Abad Lake

ATTA ABADE-NAGAR VALLEY -KARIMABAD Atta Abad Lake- Hoper –: 36 kms/1.5 hours’ drive Hoper- Karimabad: 23 kms/45 minutes’ drive Today, we will visit Nagar valley, Dong Rock Inscriptions and Ganish. Overnight in Karimabad. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Dong Rock Inscriptions • Stop at Ultar & Lady Finger View Point • Hoper Nagar Valley • Ganish Cluster- the oldest settlement in Hunza

CENTRAL HUNZA Full day tour of central Hunza. Overnight in Karimabad Hunza. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Baltit Fort • Karimabad Bazaar • Walk Along Barbar Water Channel • Altit Fort • Altit Cluster/Altit Village • Sunset from the Eagle’s Nest View Point in Duiker
CENTRAL HUNZA Day at leisure to enjoy the natural beautify of Hunza without any activity. Overnight in Karimabad Hunza.

Today you will spend the day visiting the Qissa khawani bazaar (Story telling bazaar), as this where traders along the Silk route would stop to grab a bite to eat and exchange stories of their travel whilst sipping on some green tea. Aside from its historical significance for traders, Qissa Khawani also boasts a famous food street. Karimabad Humza -Skardu: 290 kms/6.5 hours’ drive Skardu – Shigir: 45 kms/ 1 hour’s drive Drive from Karimabad Hunza to Shigir valley via Skardu. Overnight in Shigir KEY ATTRACTIONS • Visit the unique place near Juglot, where three great Mountain ranges; the Karakoram, the Himalaya & Hindukush meet • Nanga Parbat viewpoint • Drive along the River Indus

DESOAI NATIONAL PARK Day excursion to Deosai National park and back to Shigir for overnight stay. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Deosai plateau • Sadpara Lake • Chota Pani • Bara Pani • Sheosar Lake • Great spot for photography of flora and fauna

SHIGIR-KHAPLU-SHIGIR Shigir-Khaplu: 120 kms/2.5 hours’ drive Day excursion to Khaplu and drive back to Shigir for overnight stay. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Indus Shyok River meeting point • Khapulo Fort • Chaqchan Mosque
Full day to explore attractions around Skardu. Overnight in Shigir. KEY ATTRACTIONS • Amburiq Mosque Shigir • Manthal Buddha Rock • Kharpocho Fort • Sarfaranga Cold Desert

SKARDU – ISLAMABAD – TAXILA 1/2 day to explore Taxila. Overnight in Islamabad KEY ATTRACTIONS • Taxila Museum-showcasing antiques and artifacts of Gandhara civilization • Julian Buddhist Stupa & Monastery • Dharmarajika complex and stupa • Truck painting workshop -time permitting
Day in Islamabad, at leisure or you can spend half the day visiting Saidpur Village & Bari Imam Shrines.

generalInfo:
Embark on this spectacular voyage at Islamabad, the political & administrative city of Pakistan. The capital is guarded by Karakoram giants, Hunza Valley nestles itself in the lap of snow-capped mountains, which makes it a tourist delight. The enchanting beauty of Hunza's reaches its peak in the apricot & cherry blossom in spring, the valley turns green in summer & leaves change their colours to red, yellow & orange in the autumn season around end of October / November.

The magical Karimabad (Baltit), the formal capital of Hunza Valley has a charm of its own, encircled by breathtakingly beautiful snow-capped peaks, lush green fields, fruit orchards & the singing Hunza River, the feeling of being here is unmatchable. Views from a fairytale like Baltit Fort, the old residence of the Mirs of Hunza standing atop Karimabad are incredibly beautiful. A walk along the Barbar irrigation channel with striking views of Rakaposhi, Diran Peak and Golden Peak add more essence to your journey. The beautiful Gulmit valley surrounded by high mountains and glaciers, and the Passu village known for Passu Glacier, Batura Glacier and Passu Cones are worth visiting. The smiling, welcoming and friendly inhabitants of Hunza truly make your stay at home.

In the second part of the trip, we will explore Baltistan. In the extreme north of Pakistan, Skardu is an epitome of beauty, serenity, and wilderness. It is located amidst an impressive landscape; towering mountains, deep gorges, cascading waterfalls, creeping glaciers, and quiet lakes constitute this rugged beauty. This tour takes us to heaven on earth. Skardu is the gateway to the world’s highest peaks, which include K-2, Broad Peak, Gasherbrum I, Gasherbrum II, and hundreds of peaks over 6000 metres high.

Encircling the heart-shaped Kachura Lake is surrounded by fruit-laden orchards and flower-filled gardens, and the breath-taking view presents a heavenly atmosphere. The Kharpocho Fort looking down the hills, the crystal clear water of Satpara Lake, the impressive Shigar and Khapulo Forts, and the Deosai, which is the second highest plateau in the world: let’s explore beautiful Baltistan, also known as "Little Tibet."

Finally, we will visit Lahore, the cultural capital of Pakistan. It is a city steeped in history, culture, and natural beauty. From its magnificent Mughal-era architecture to its lush gardens and bustling bazaars, Lahore has something for everyone. The city is a testament to the rich cultural heritage that is why Lahore is known as “the Cultural Capital of Pakistan”.

Lahore is a must-visit for anyone interested in history, culture & food. With its vibrant colours, exquisite designs & warm hospitality, Lahore is a city that will capture your heart and leave you with memories that will last a lifetime.

There are group tour dates but this tour can also be done as a private tour. The recommended duration for this tour would be 21 days to enjoy it at a steady pace.

Cheaper options are available.

dayInfo.description: ISLAMABAD: Arrival at the Islamabad International Airport, transfer to hotel. City tour of Islamabad after a short rest at the hotel to freshen up. Today’s visits/activities include: Shah Faisal Mosque, Lok Virsa (Folk Heritage) Museum, Pakistan National Monument, Daman-e-Koh (Islamabad view point), and Parliament House, President House, Prime Minister House, and Supreme Court of Pakistan (external view)

ISLAMABAD - SKARDU: Flight from Islamabad to Skardu. Half day tour Skardu and surrounding attractions. The key attractions you will be taken to are; Upper Kachura Lake, Kachura Choq, and Shangri-La Resort.
SKARDU: Full day to explore attractions around Skardu. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Manthal Buddha Rock, Kharpocho Fort, Sarfaranga Cold Desert, Shigir Fort, and Amburiq Mosque Shigir.

SKARDU: Day excursion to Deosai National Park or Khaplu. Drive back to Skardu for overnight stay. Skardu-Khaplu: 95 kms/2.5 hours’ drive one-way (excl. stops, daily time in the car 5 hours). Skardu-Sheosar Lake: 70 kms/4 hours’ drive one-way (excl. stops). KEY ATTRACTIONS-KHAPLU: Indus Shyok River meeting point, Khapulo Fort, and Chaqchan Mosque.

SKARDU – GILGIT: Skardu – Gilgit: 192 kms/4.5 hours’ drive (excluding stops). After a late breakfast, we will drive from Skardu to Gilgit along the Indus River, making stops at various attractions. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Drive along the River Indus, Nanga Parbat viewpoint, and Visit the unique place near Juglot, where three great mountain ranges -the Karakoram, the Himalaya & the Hindukush meet.

GILGIT – KARIMABAD HUNZA: Gilgit – Karimabad Hunza: 100 kms/2 hours’ drive (excl. any stops). Visit Gilgit in the morning, then proceed to Karimabad Hunza, travelling on the Karakoram Highway along the Hunza River. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Kargah Rock Buddha, Gilgit Bazaar, including suspension bridge, The collision point of continental plates near Chalt, Rakaposhi Viewpoint Ghulmet, and Ganish Cluster- the oldest settlement in Hunza.

CENTRAL HUNZA: Full day tour of central Hunza. Overnight in Karimabad Hunza. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Karimabad Bazaar, Visit to Baltit Fort, Walk along the Barbar Water Channel followed by a lunch with a local family, Altit Fort, Altit Cluster/Altit Village, Shiqam project- women artisans at work, and Sunset from the Eagle’s Nest Viewpoint in Duiker.
CENTRAL HUNZA: Day at leisure

NAGAR VALLEY & UPPER HUNZA: Karimabad – Hoper: 23 kms/45 minutes’ drive. Hoper – Atta Abad Lake: 36 kms/1.5 hours’ drive. In the morning visit Ganish, the oldest settle of Hunza Valley followed by Nagar and then proceed towards upper Hunza. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Ganish Cluster- the oldest settlement in Hunza, Hoper Nagar Valley, Stop at Ultar & Lady Finger view point, Dong Rock Inscriptions, Atta Abad Lake, and Gulmit Village.

UPPER HUNZA – GILGIT: Atta Abad Lake – Passu: 20 kms/30 minutes drive. Passu - Gilgit: 145km / 3.5 hours drive. The first half of the day, we will take you to explore the beautiful valley of upper Hunza. In the afternoon we will drive back to Gilgit. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Hussaini Bridge, Passu Cones/Passu Cathedrals view point, Batura Glacier viewpoint, Borith Lake, Danyor suspension bridge (optional), and Kargah Buddha.

Flight from Gilgit to Islamabad. Upon arrival transfer Taxila to visit Archaeological sites. Or drive to Naran or Besham if flight does not operate. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Taxila Museum-showcasing antiques and artifacts of Gandhara civilization, Julian Buddhist Stupa & Monastery, Dharmarajika complex and stupa, and Truck painting workshop. The number of attractions covered will depend upon the timing of the Gilgit - Islamabad flight and whether it operates.

ISLAMABAD - LAHORE: There are two options available for traveling from Islamabad to Lahore. Traveling to Lahore visiting historical Rohtas Fort or traveling via Katas Raj Temple and Khewra Salt Mines. Islamabad - Katas Raj Temple: 156 kms / 2.5 hours’ drive (travel time only, excludes stops). Katas Raj Temple-Khewra Salt Mines: 22 kms / 50 minutes’ drive. Khewra Salt Mines – Lahore: 260 kms/3.5 hours’ drive. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Katas Raj Temple, and Khewra Salt Mines - Asia’s biggest and world second largest salt mines. Note: The day will be long, so you can either skip the temple or the Khewra Salt Mines if either of these are not a significant attraction for you.

LAHORE: Full day tour of historical sites/places of interest in Lahore. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Lahore Fort -built by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan, Badshahi Masjid built between 1671 & 1673 by Mughal emperors, Anarkali Bazaar, Food street, and Musical program at Lahore Fort in the evening (subject to availability).

LAHORE: Another full day tour of historical sites/places of interest in Lahore including flag ceremony at Pakistan-India border. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Mausoleums of Jahangir & Noor Jahan in Lahore, Lahore Museum -Showcasing one of the largest and most representative collections of miniature paintings in the subcontinent, Visit Shalimar Garden (optional), and Experience the flag ceremony at the Wagah, the border between Pakistan & India.

LAHORE: Half day at leisure. In the afternoon, a rikshaw tour of Lahore. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Rikshaw tour of walled city gates, including Akbari Gate, Delhi Gate, and Spice Bazaar. Visit Masjid Wazir Khan-built by Wazir Khan, the viceroy of Punjab, during the reign of the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan. Shahi Hammam -a Persian-style bath that was built during the reign of Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan.

LAHORE TO ISLAMABAD VIA RHOTAS FORT: Lahore- Rohtas Fort: 252 kms/4 hours’ drive. Rohtas Fort- Islamabad: 113 kms/2.5 hours’ drive. After breakfast, departure for Islamabad. Visit Rohtas Fort and Raja Bazaar Rawalpindi on the way. KEY ATTRACTIONS: Part of Grand Trunk Road (GT Road), Rohtas Fort to experience Mughal architecture, and Raja Bazaar Rawalpindi.
ISLAMABAD: Transfer to airport for return to respective countries.

placesVisited: Islamabad, Faisal Mosque, Kaghan Valley, Naran, Fairy Meadows, Indus River, Rama Lake, Dosai Plateau, Skardu, Khaplu Fort, Baleygon school visit, Hunza, Hoper Glacier, Kalash Valley, Ayun, Taxila
generalInfo:
This itinerary has the capacity to enthrall even the worldliest of travellers. From mountain scenery that will make your heart leap to lively markets and azure lakes, absorbing cultural encounters and historic forts. While every day offers something to fire your imagination, there are several gems worth dwelling on in detail.

You’ll spend a few days hiking around the mountainous Hunza Valley, with a backdrop of cathedral peaks, pristine lakes and the Hoper Glacier, and staying in a clifftop hotel offering dramatic views. Later in the trip you’ll arrive in the otherworldly Kalash Valley, and take part in the celebrations around the Uchao Festival. And in Ayun you’ll visit the home of one of the princes of Chitral, and take a stroll through his elegant gardens.

Then of course there is Fairy Meadows, known locally as Joot, a pristine national park at the foot of Nanga Parbat. These alpine grasslands and forests overlooked by snowy peaks are an absolutely stunning place to walk.

Other moments to treasure – the open-top jeep ride through the Hushe Valley to meet the children at a local school; crossing the famous Indus River, and driving across the Dosai Plateau with the Karakoram Mountains in the foreground.

The communities you’ll visit will often be remote, rarely encountering western travellers, but no less the welcoming for it. Staying in homestays and family-run guesthouses, and using local guides, this tour brings vital income to areas of Pakistan that are still well beyond the main tourist track. It feels pretty good to be a trailblazer, right?

Please note that we have two festival departures - the Shandur Polo Festival starting in June, and the Kalash Uchaw Festival in August. The durations of the tours may vary so please see individual itineraries for details.

dayInfo.description: Tour starts in Islamabad: Today the tour starts in Islamabad, 'City of Islam', Pakistan's capital city. It replaced Karachi back in the 1967 and is now the political and commercial heart of the country. Situated against the lush backdrop of the Margalla Hills it is a city where old and new collide. Leafy green boulevards are home to modern buildings, and shopping malls, but also dotted with traditional homes and mosques. After checking in to our rooms, available from 14:00 or possibly earlier, we have the chance to visit some of the famous sights of Islamabad including the Faisal Mosque, the largest in South Asia, and one of the largest mosques in the world, accommodating up to 100,000 worshippers at any one time. We will also take time to visit the Lok Virsa Museum, the first state museum of ethnology in Pakistan, representing the history and astounding diversity of country’s living traditions. We will also visit the Pakistan Monument and take in the views of the city from Daman-koh, a hilltop garden on the northern side of the city.

Islamabad - Ayun: This morning we’ll leave very early to drive this spectacular journey, through the Lowari Tunnel and up through the frontier, towards Ayun. This is a full day’s drive and we will not reach our hotel in Ayun until the evening for a well-earned rest.

Ayun - Kalash: After breakfast we will drive in to the Kalash Valley of Rumbor and the village of Balanguru where we stay with our good friend Saifullah Jan, the chief spokesperson for the colourful Kalash people. The journey takes about two hours, though if people prefer we can walk the last few miles through the gorgeous valley. After lunch we will meet the Kalash and go for walks around the village, or further afield to visit some of our friends in Grum or Kalashagrum.

In the Kalash: Village & Valley Walks: Today we maximise our time by walking in and around the valley to enjoy the local scenery and experience the local hospitality. This morning we should be able to take a walk up in the direction of the Afghan frontier to visit some small villages. We return to Balanguru for lunch and then for those who wish to we head out on another walk around the valley to understand more of the lifestyle of the Kalash people. These walks are optional, and you may wish to spend your time relaxing in the village.

Kalash - Chitral: After breakfast we spend our last morning with The Kalash before driving on to Chitral. In the late afternoon we’ll travel on towards Chitral National Park to see the markhor, a kind of mountain antelope and favoured prey of the snow leopards, before checking into our lovely local hotel and have dinner.

Chitral 3800m approx - Mastuj: Another beautiful and dramatic drive takes us we winding our way along the Mastuj Valley, passing Tirich Mir and Boni Zong. After lunch we will be taking a short walk up to the main road to capture views of the Tirich Mir Peak. We can also see the Yarkhun Valley at the top of which lies Afghanistan’s Wakhan Corridor.

Mastuj 3800m approx - Ghizer Valley: Today is probably the most spectacular drive of the tour as we make our way across the Phander and Laspur valleys, not forgetting the drive over the Shandur Pass. Here we stop for tea at the top of the pass at 3,800 metres. Shandur boasts the highest polo field in the world, where the best teams from Gilgit and Chitral play very fast and aggressive matches. Nearby the Shandur Lake is famous for the vivid reflections of lofty Hindu Kush mountains that surround it. The Langer is a beautiful plain used for grazing the yaks and dzos – where we’ll enjoy a nice picnic lunch and then drive on to the Ghizer Valley, our resting place for this evening.

Ghizer Valley - Hunza: After breakfast we will then drive to Gilgit, and onwards to Hunza. We know we use a lot of superlatives in this dossier but this trip really is epic, particularly as you round the corner and see the titanic form of Mount Rakaposhi basking in the sun, right beside the road. We will take lunch on the way – at the Rakaposhi View Restaurant – before continuing on to Hunza. On arrival we will have the chance to explore the laid back little town of Karimabad and admire the mountains that surround it before continuing on to our hotel which is situated in a spectacular location, 2,850m above sea level, and 500m above the valley floor with panoramic views of five 7,000m peaks!

In Hunza: After breakfast we visit the famous Baltit Fort, restored by the Aga Khan Trust for Culture to a fantastic standard. It is now a UNESCO World Heritage Centre. We will then take lunch in town. In the afternoon those that wish can have a water channel walk down around Karimabad before having a wander around the local shops where there will be plenty to buy. Café De Hunza serves best coffee and walnut cake in town

Hunza - Attabad Lake - Hunza: Wake at around 5:30 to watch the rising sun turn the peak of Rakaposhi flamingo pink...optional of course! After breakfast we will first drive to the other side of the valley to take a look at the Hoper Glacier. After this we’ll have lunch in a pretty garden café before driving an hour and a half further up the KKH to visit the newly formed lake at Attabad. In January 2010 a massive landslide blocked the Hunza River, which submerged 28kms of the KKH by forming a beautiful azure lake. At Gulmit we visit a carpet weaving centre run by very friendly Wakhi women. A little later we drive further north up to Batura Glacier, the fifth longest in world, and enjoy the stunning views of Passu Cones, the white Passu Glacier, and a number of 7000m peaks. In the late afternoon we return to Karimabad.

Hunza - Gilgit: This morning we end our time in Hunza and head back down to Gilgit. We will have a chance to take a look around this classic frontier town, once considered the furthest outpost of the empire. We will see the Christian graveyard and the bazaar, before heading to our hotel for the evening.

Gilgit - Skardu - Khaplu: Today we will take a day long drive to Khaplu. Following the Indus most of the way, this is a hugely impressive journey. We will take lunch along the way before arriving into Khaplu in the early evening.

Khaplu - Hushe Valley - Khaplu (3050m approx): Today the adventure continues as we follow the Shyok and Hushe Rivers into the heart of the Karakoram. Draining an enormous area of the eastern Karakoram, much of which is now in India, the Shyok and Hushe rivers cut a spectacular trail into this eastern most part of Baltistan. We'll drive up the Hushe Valley, where we have the opportunity to visit our foundation-sponsored school in the remote village of Baleygon. From here we’ll continue further up the valley to Marzigone where we see the magnificent 7,000m Mashabrum Mountain standing sentinel ahead of us. In the late afternoon, as the sun is setting, we’ll return to Khaplu.
Khaplu - Skardu: This morning we’ll drice to Skardu where we'll visit the old bazaar, and then head out to see the Manthal Buddha rock carving just outside of town.

Skardu – Deosai Plateau - Astore (4100m approx): This morning we are continuing our journey to the amazing Deosai Plateau National Park. This plateau is a stunning 4,000m high wildlife wilderness complete with an array of wild flowers at this time of year. We’ll enjoy a hearty picnic lunch with views of the Himalayas before continuing on to Astore.

Astore - Fairy Meadows (3300m approx): This morning after an early breakfast we’ll leave Astore and drive to Raikot Bridge. Here we’ll transfer to jeeps for the short, but wildly dramatic, drive to the road head before walking up to the cabins at Fairy Meadows. The walk is of a moderate nature on a good mountain path and should take around 3 hours. We will enjoy the views of Nanga Parbat – or Naked Mountain (the 8,100m peak and massif that marks the western end of the Himalayas). Here we will stay in the rustic log cabins, all of which have commanding views of the great mountain. This is truly one of the most magical places on earth.

In Fairy Meadows (3300m approx): Today we walk through the forested foothills of the massif to the Beyal Camp and back. This will not be too strenuous, as we will run along the contours rather than straight up, but it will be spectacular. Anyone wanting a more relaxed time can stay at the meadows, which is a lovely place to unwind. We will take lunch at a local camp and return to have dinner back at the cabins.

Fairy Meadows - Naran (4173m approx): This morning after an early breakfast we’ll walk back to the road head, pick up the jeeps and re-join the KKH. We’ll drive for another couple of hours, before heading over the spectacular Babusa Pass, before driving on to Naran for the night.

Naran - Islamabad: It is an early start this morning to make our long drive south, through the Kaghan Valley, stopping for lunch en route and then for the evening at the hotel in Islamabad. The journey will take about six to seven hours.

Islamabad - Taxila - Islamabad: Today we will have a relaxed start and take a short drive to Taxila to explore this fascinating Buddhist university town, dating back to the Gandaharan era of Alexander the Great. We’ll then return to Islamabad for some last minute shopping and our farewell dinner.
Tour ends.: Today the tour ends after breakfast in Islamabad.

tourName: Shandur Polo festival and cultural tour in Pakistan
generalInfo:
Located at an altitude if 3700m / 12,200 feet above sea level, Shandur Pass is the highest mountain pass, which connects the Chitral & Gilgit Baltistan regions. It is often referred to as 'The Roof of the World' due to its high altitude & stunning panoramic views of the surrounding mountains. The pass is also known for its annual polo festival that takes place in July, which attracts visitors from all over the world.

Shandur invites visitors to experience a traditional polo tournament between the teams of Chitral & Gilgit in July every year. The festivals include folk music, dancing & a camping village. The first polo tournament took place at Shandur Pass in 1936. A British Political agent Major Cobb, who was fond of playing polo under a full moon, nicknamed the polo ground in Shandur named 'Moony Polo Ground'. This event is like Pakistan's equivalent of Glastonbury, attracting visitors from all over Pakistan to come and camp there for 3 nights.

This trip also includes a visit to Hunza, Ghizer, Chitral & Kailash Valleys. the trip combines cultural experiences, driving through enchanting valleys & experiencing freestyle polo tournaments.

This is a great way to help the local economy of Pakistan as much of the trip entails visiting local small bazaars with shops run by the local people and staying in local hotels. The prices quoted have been based on budget accommodation to make Pakistan accessible to a wider audience, however this can be upgraded for those who prefer more luxury accommodation and are able to afford it.

Please note that you can also do this tour privately.

This tour will go ahead even if we just get 2 people booked on it, if people are willing to pay the higher price of £3,200.

dayInfo.description: Arrival in Islamabad – Discover the Capital Your journey begins upon arrival at Islamabad International Airport, where you'll be greeted and transferred to your hotel. After a short rest, embark on a city tour of Islamabad, an oasis of serenity amidst green hills. Marvel at the grand Shah Faisal Mosque, one of the largest mosques in the world. Dive into the cultural heritage at the Lok Virsa Museum and enjoy panoramic views of the city from Daman-e-Koh. Uncover historical gems at the Golra Sharif Railway Museum, and drive past the iconic landmarks of Parliament House and the President's House, soaking in the contemporary spirit of Pakistan’s capital.

Fly to Gilgit – Journey to the Heart of Hunza A morning flight will whisk you to Gilgit, where the true adventure begins. From there, embark on a scenic 2-hour drive to Karimabad, Hunza, a land renowned for its towering peaks and ancient cultures. Spend the afternoon exploring the picturesque Hunza Valley. Visit the historic Baltit Fort, shop for traditional crafts in the lively Karimabad Bazaar, and stroll along the Barbar Water Channel, an architectural marvel. Bask in the tranquility of Rakaposhi View Point, where the snow-capped peak of Rakaposhi dominates the horizon.

Explore Central Hunza and Nagar Valleys Today, immerse yourself in the unparalleled beauty of the Hunza and Nagar valleys. Visit the peaceful Hoper Valley and enjoy breathtaking views at the Ultar and Lady Finger viewpoints. Take an optional hike to the majestic Barpu Glacier or visit the ancient Altit Fort, perched on a cliff. Witness history unfold at the Altit Village and Altit Cluster before ending your day watching the sun set from Duiker, at the famed Eagle’s Nest View Point, offering panoramic vistas of the surrounding mountains.

Visit Upper Hunza and the Stunning Atta Abad Lake Travel to Upper Hunza, home to the breathtaking Atta Abad Lake. Its vivid turquoise waters, set against a backdrop of towering mountains, are the result of a natural disaster turned wonder. You’ll visit the ancient Ganish Village, the oldest settlement in Hunza, and admire rock carvings at Dong. Traverse the nerve-testing Hussaini Bridge, one of the most precarious bridges in the world, and stand in awe of the towering Passu Cones and Cathedrals.

Onward to Phander – The Gem of Ghizer Today’s journey takes you deeper into the rugged beauty of northern Pakistan. A scenic 7-hour drive will lead you from Gilgit to Phander, passing lush valleys, small villages, and the sacred Kargah Buddha, a centuries-old Buddhist rock carving. Travel along the Ghizer River, stopping to admire the beauty of local villages before arriving in Phander, known for its serene, cobalt-blue lake.

Phander to Shandur Pass – Gateway to the Roof of the World After a restful night in Phander, continue your journey to the legendary Shandur Pass, the highest polo ground in the world, sitting at 3,700 meters above sea level. En route, you’ll pass Phander Lake, an oasis of calm surrounded by lush greenery. Settle into camp near Shandur and prepare for the cultural spectacle of the Shandur Polo Festival.

Shandur Polo Festival – Experience the Magic Over the next two days, immerse yourself in the grand tradition of freestyle polo at the Shandur Polo Festival, where the rugged teams from Chitral and Gilgit face off in a thrilling match. Beyond the polo, enjoy lively music and traditional dancing, all set against the dramatic backdrop of the Karakoram and Hindukush mountain ranges. Campsites surround the festival grounds, providing a unique way to connect with nature and the vibrant local culture.

Journey to Chitral – Explore Its Rich History Depart from Shandur Pass and journey to Chitral, a valley steeped in history and surrounded by majestic peaks. Visit the Chitral Fort, a relic of the valley’s storied past, and explore the grand Shahi Mosque (Royal Mosque), an architectural gem. Enjoy the day wandering through this enchanting town, nestled beneath the towering Tirich Mir mountain.

Discover the Kalash Valleys Today, visit the captivating Kalash Valley, home to the ancient Kalash people, a unique and vibrant community.
